markdownText.value: Core `Pure` (coressponding to `###Pure` section in `Pure`) concerns with fundamental modelling concepts, such as, classes (data models), enumerations, associations, functions, etc.

`Mapping DSL` (coressponding to `###Mapping` section in `Pure`) concerns with data transformation specifications: this includes model-to-model transformation, store specification to model transformation, etc.
`Connection DSL` (coressponding to `###Connection` section in `Pure`) concerns with data stores access
`Runtime DSL` (coressponding to `###Runtime` section in `Pure`) concerns with the organization/grouping and contextual usage of connections
`External Store Relational DSL` (coressponding to `###Relational` section in `Pure`) concerns with mappings, connections, and specifications for relational databases

es-relational.grammar.parser.title: What is External Store Relational DSL about?

markdownText.value: `Service DSL` (coressponding to `###Service` section in `Pure`) concerns with generation and deployment of Pure query to productionize data extraction and exploration

dsl-external-format.grammar.parser.title: What is External Format DSL about?

markdownText.value: `External Format DSL` (coressponding to `###ExternalFormat` section in `Pure`) concerns with the serialization between data models and external formats like CSV, JSON, etc.
`Generation Specification DSL` (coressponding to `###GenerationSpecification` section in `Pure`) concerns with organization of generation pipeline

dsl-generation-specification.grammar.par.title: What is Generation Specification DSL about?

markdownText.value: `File Generation DSL` (coressponding to `###FileGeneration` section in `Pure`) concerns with generating models in external formats (e.g. Avro, Protobuf, JSON Schema, etc.)

dsl-file-generation.grammar.parser.title: What is File Generation DSL about?

markdownText.value: `Data DSL` (coressponding to `###Data` section in `Pure`) concerns with storing data which can be various purpose including testing
A `Class` specifies a data model's structure, inheritance, and constraints
A `Profile` provides a generic extension mechanism for customizing existing data models; some of its uses include documentating and classifying data models
An `Enumeration` specifies the complete list of value that a given type may acquire
A `Measure` (fairly similar to `Enumeration`) specifies a measurble type: it specifies units (as well as conversion functions to convert values between them)
An `Association` specifies a linking between between 2 data models
A `Function` specifies a piece of reusable Pure code logic
A `Mapping` specifies a transformation between models, including model-to-model, store-to-model, enumeration-to-model, etc.
A `Database` specifies the structure (schema, table, view) and joins of a relational database
A `Service` specifies query execution and deployment information so the it can be productionized: e.g. exposing it via API endpoints
A `Runtime` specifies a logical grouping of connections which can be used for query execution
A `Connection` specifies access to data store(s) including data store specifications and authentication strategies
A `Binding` element specifies the association between a set of models and their corresponding schemas in external formats (e.g. JSON, CSV, etc.) to ensure the models and schemas always kept in-sync
A `Schema-set` element specifies schemas in external formats (e.g. JSON, CSV, etc.), from which Pure models can be generated
A `Generation Specification` provides the pipeline for all generations

dsl-generation-specification.concept.ele.title: What is a generation specification element?

markdownText.value: A `File Generation Specification` specifies the generation of external format from Pure models

dsl-file-generation.concept.element.file.title: What is a file generation specification element?

markdownText.value: A `Data` element stores data which can be used for various purposes, including testing
A JSON model connection specifies access to a model store where the retrieved data will be in JSON format

dsl-mapping.grammar.connection.json-mode.title: What is a JSON model connection?

markdownText.value: A XML model connection specifies access to a model store where the retrieved data will be in XML format

dsl-mapping.grammar.connection.xml-model.title: What is a XML model connection?

markdownText.value: A model chain connection provides a mechanism to sequence mappings (data transformations) and simulate a data store

dsl-mapping.grammar.connection.model-cha.title: What is a model chain connection?

markdownText.value: A relational data connection specifies access to a relational database, including the store specification and authentication strategy

es-relational.grammar.connection.relatio.title: What is a relational database connection?

markdownText.value: A `domain-specific language` (DSL) is a higher-level abstraction optimized for a specific domain/class of problems. Each `DSL` often has their own `Pure` sub-grammar, which partition `Pure` code into sections (each starts with a header, such as `###Pure`, `###Mapping`, etc.

markdownText.value: `Text DSL` (corresponding to header `###DataSpace` section in `Pure`) concerns with storing data in plain-text
A `Text` element stores plain-text content with a specified content-type, which can be used for formatting, syntax-highlighting
`Diagram DSL`  (corresponding to `###Diagram` section in `Pure`) concerns with visualizing data models and their relationship
A `Diagram` element specifies the visualization/rendering of data models and their relationship
`DataSpace DSL` (corresponding to header `###DataSpace` section in `Pure`) concerns with providing information and documentation about the taxonomy of data models

A `Data-space` element specifies a grouping of model diagrams, execution context (mapping, runtime), test data, and so on to help communicate about the _meaning_, _usage_, and relationships of data models and to help users quickly explore and understand the models
`Persistence DSL` (corresponding to `###Persistence` section in `Pure`) provides specifications for persisting the result of a service invocation into a target data store

A `Persistence` element consists of a trigger to initiate persistence, a service to source and transform data, and a persister describing how to write to the target (e.g. ingest mode [snapshot | delta | append-only], temporality [non-temporal | unitemporal | bitemporal], and transactional semantics)

A `PersistenceContext` element refers to a `Persistence` element, defines the runtime platform for persistence (e.g. AWS Glue), and may include additional runtime platform and environment details necessary for execution (e.g. data source connections, authentication strategies, and service input parameters)

dsl-persistence.concept.element.persiste.title: What is a persistence context element?

markdownText.value: `External Store Service DSL` (corresponding to `###ServiceStore` section in `Pure`) concerns with data store specifications which enable accessing data from API endpoints

es-service.grammar.parser.title: What is External Store Service DSL about?

markdownText.value: A service store element specifies API endpoints as data source

es-service.concept.element.service-store.title: What is a service store element?

markdownText.value:
Your SDLC project pipeline could rely on various platform dependencies (e.g. `engine`, `sdlc`, etc.). By default, these platform dependencies' versions are not specfied, meaning that when the CI pipeline is running, the versions to be used will be derived from the latest version of `sdlc`. This means your pipeline effectively operates on progressing/moving platforms. The upside of this is the project automatically gets the benefit of newer releases (bug fixes, new features, etc.), but it could once in a while yield unexpected results.

 Sometimes, this might be less desirable; for example, your pipeline produces artifacts that you need to depend on so you would like to stabilize these artifacts. In these cases, freezing the platform dependencies' versions would be a sound approach. Otherwise, we highly recommend you not to fix these dependencies' versions.

question.when-to-configure-project-platf.title: When should I configure the versions of project platform dependencies

dsl-service.setup.productionize-query.title: What does it mean to productionize a query?

markdownText.value: To `productionize` a query is to turn it into a `service`. This service will need to be injected into a **SDLC** project, so it can be reviewed, committed, released, and deployed to production environment

dsl-service.setup.productionize-query.qu.title: When should I enable auto-configuration while productionizing query?

markdownText.value:
While `productionizing` a query, it is recommended that you should ensure that the service created will not break compilation. As such, we support `auto-configuration` for the workspace: this is our best effort to ensure the workspace has adequate and appropriate metadata (e.g. dependencies, models, mappings, runtimes, etc.) to make the service _just work_

Usually, if the chosen project is the same as the query's project, no further configuration is needed, hence, it's safe to opt-out of `auto-configuration`; otherwise it's almost always safer to use `auto-configuration`
